The image is reproduced with permission from [236-238]. 5.1.6. Transducers for physical stimuli Several types of inorganic nanoparticles can be used as versatile transducers that convert physical stimuli into other forms (Fig. 13). For instance, magnetic nanoparticles can convert magnetic fields into mechanical force or heat, and AuNPs can transform light into heat. Notably in this regard, transducer nanoparticles can be controlled in vivo in a remote-controlled manner because the external energy source signals (e.g., magnetic field or light) penetrate biological tissue non-invasively. When applied to magnetic nanoparticles composed of Fe3O4, oscillating magnetic fields in the kHz to MHz range generate heat via two mechanisms, the Brownian modes and Neél modes. 53 Brownian modes produce heat through the friction arising from particle oscillations, whereas Neél modes do so via the magnetic moment-rotation that occurs with each field oscillation [289]. Accordingly, iron oxide nanoparticles have been extensively investigated for their applications to hyperthermal therapy. In addition, the high penetration of the magnetic field makes iron oxide-based hyperthermal therapy one of the more promising cancer therapies in the biomedical area [70]. AuNPs are efficient transducers that convert light into heat through rapid relaxation of surface plasmon resonance (SPR), which in this case involves the excitation of free electrons of gold atoms when exposed to light, leading to a state of collective oscillation [290]. Zhao et al. constructed anti-epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) peptide-conjugated PEGylated triangular AuNPs (TGN-PEG-P75) to eradicate non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), which is notoriously difficult to treat [240]. TGN has a strong NIR absorption window, high photothermal conversion efficacy, and good biocompatibility. The peptide P75 promotes selective accumulation of TGN-PEG-P75 in the tumor site. TGN-PEG-P75 exhibits high photothermal conversion efficiency in vivo, resulting in successful tumor ablation through the photo-induced thermal effect. 54 Figure 13. Medical devices Over the last decade, new medical applications of hybrid nanocomposites have emerged, and most of these applications require multiple functionalities of hydrogel networks and dynamic interactions between the surrounding matrices and cells [177, 179-181]. Innovative advances in polymer chemistry, nanotechnologies, and biomolecular engineering have allowed us to overcome limitations in the design of nanocomposite materials with customized 55 functionality. In this section, among various applications of nanocomposite materials, we will focus on biomedical applications related to scaffolds for tissue engineering, vascular stents, and dental materials (Table 3). 5.2.1. Scaffolds for tissue engineering Polymer scaffolds (porous scaffolds, hydrogels, or films) lack the required mechanical strength and in vivo degradation characteristics, particularly for load-bearing regenerative applications. Therefore, in recent years, interest has grown in the development of nanocomposite scaffolds that can overcome the limitations of conventional polymer scaffolds [292, 293]. Nanocomposite scaffolds can be tuned to mimic the physical and chemical properties of native tissues using various nanomaterials, including silicate-based, CaP, carbon- based, and metal/metal oxide nanoparticles that have been physically or chemically combined with synthetic or natural polymers. Tailored nanocomposite scaffolds can provide a 3D network, porosity, solute diffusion properties, nano (micro)-structured surfaces, tunable surface chemistry properties, tissue-mimetic elasticity, hydrophilicity, and mechanical stiffness [294-298]. These advantageous properties of nanocomposite scaffolds allow for better cell– matrix interaction, guided migration, cell proliferation, and/or cell differentiation. Silicate-based nanomaterials are widely used due to their hydrophilic nature and large surface areas, which are easy to functionalize with bioactive molecules such as growth factors and cell-adhesive ligands. These functional moieties in turn improve their tissue regeneration capacity and biocompatibility at much higher doses than most other nanomaterials; moreover, the degradation products are non-toxic, absorbable, and related to osteogenic cell function [188, 299-302]. For instance, 2D Laponite-loaded GelMA hydrogels promote osteogenesis of preosteoblasts in the absence of any osteoinductive factors (Fig. 14a) [188]. Laponite 56 nanoplatelets incorporating regenerated silk fibroin (RSF) form an injectable RSF/Laponite nanocomposite hydrogel with potential for application in repair of irregular bone defects [245]. Halloysite nanotubes (HNTs), dioctahedral clay minerals, and incorporated porous chitosan– agarose–gelatin nanocomposite scaffolds exhibit excellent resorption within 6 weeks after implantation; in addition, neo-vascularization in the new connective tissue penetrates the implanted nanocomposite scaffold [246]. In another example, biodegradable and osteoblast- bearing nanocomposite hydrogel constructs consisting of PEGDA/Laponite and HA, intended for applications related to bone regeneration, were developed via a two-channel 3D-bioprinting method (Fig. 14b) [247]. Due to their promising mechanical properties, biocompatibility, osteoconductivity, and resorbability, CaP nanoparticles, including hydroxyapatite and -tricalcium phosphate, are the most extensively used nanomaterials for bone regeneration applications involving incorporation of nanocomposite scaffolds. For instance, CaP nanoparticles embedded in HABP nanocomposite hydrogels exhibit self-healing capability, adhesion to mineral surfaces, and the ability to interact with bone, as demonstrated by bone ingrowth following implantation of the hydrogels (Fig. 14c) [30]. Nanocomposite scaffolds consisting of cryogenic 3D-printed hierarchical porous CaP/poly(L-lactic acid) (PLLA) loaded with recombinant human bone morphogenetic protein-2 (rhBMP-2) exhibited successful dual delivery of rhBMP-2 and Ca2+ ions, and promoted the osteogenic differentiation of seeded human bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells (hBMSCs) [248]. Nanocomposite scaffolds composed of in situ mineralized, microporous, mechanically stiff, bioactive, and biodegradable zinc crosslinked with gellan/xanthan/bioglass exhibit improved osteoconductivity and antibacterial properties [249]. Self-assembled Ac-BP-Mg nanoparticles incorporated into MeHA/BP-Mg nanocomposite hydrogels facilitate bone regeneration without requiring the addition of cells or 57 inductive agents (Fig. 14d) [195]. Due to their favorable optical, mechanical, thermal, and electrical conductivity properties, carbon-based nanomaterials have been used to generate nanocomposite scaffolds with intriguing properties [177, 303, 304]. GelMA hydrogels incorporating CNT, which exhibit mechanical and electrical properties, improve cardiac cell adhesion, maturation, and cell–cell coupling [250]. Similarly, polyethyleneimine-functionalized GO nanosheets (fGO) carrying angiogenic genes incorporated into GelMA hydrogel improve revascularization and contractile performance in the infarcted hearts (Fig. 14e) [251]. GelMA/rGO nanocomposite hydrogels mimic the microenvironment of the cardiomyocyte ECM, and thus improve cardiac tissue morphogenesis and beating behavior (Fig. 14f) [197]. GO- and rGO-embedded thermosensitive PEG-PA hydrogels exhibit enhance chondrogenesis and adipogenesis, respectively, in tonsil-derived mesenchymal stem cells (TMSCs) (Fig. 14g) [202, 203]. Using a molding method, electrically conductive and positively charged rGOa/CNTpega/OPF/MTAC nanocomposite hydrogels were successfully fabricated into conductive nerve conduits with a positive charge and inherent incorporated conductivity, providing additional options for clinical applications in neuronal tissue engineering (Fig. 14h) [198]. Metal/metal oxide nanoparticles have been used to generate nanocomposite scaffolds responsive to elastic, thermal, and magnetic stimuli. Gold nanorods (AuNRs) incorporated into GelMA hydrogels exhibit relatively low electrical impedance and significantly higher mechanical strength [252]. Neonatal rat cardiomyocytes seeded in GelMA/AuNR nanocomposite hydrogels exhibit significant improvements in cell–matrix interaction, cell–cell coupling, and function of engineered cardiac tissue (Fig. 14i). AuNPs incorporated into GelMA hydrogel improve proliferation and osteogenic differentiation of human adipose-derived stem cells in vitro and in vivo, and the magnitude of the effect depends on the dose of AuNPs (Fig. 58 14j) [253]. Mg(OH)2 or surface-modified Mg(OH)2 nanoparticles can serve as effective neutralizers for the acidic degradation byproducts of PLA [166, 207, 254, 305]. Recently, the Han group reported the efficient anti-inflammatory effect of Mg(OH)2 nanoparticles in renal or cartilage tissue engineering by using a hybrid nanocomposite scaffold of PLGA/decellularized renal ECM/Mg(OH)2 or PLGA/Mg(OH)2, respectively (Fig. 14k and l) [18, 254]. These advanced nanocomposite scaffolds can simulate the characteristics of native tissues to a certain extent, but many problems must be overcome before they can be applied as artificial biomaterials for clinical use. For instance, a major challenge in tissue engineering is the development of biomaterials that provide biochemical and mechanical signaling cues in a gradient and sequential manner, as native ECMs do, to regulate cell proliferation, differentiation, and migration during wound healing, tissue regeneration, and homeostasis. Therefore, future efforts to design advanced nanocomposite scaffolds should focus on providing sequential physical (topography, material stiffness, and porosity) and chemical (concentration of signaling biomolecules) gradients within a nanocomposite scaffold by tuning the structure, composition, stimulus responsiveness, and controlled release of bioactive molecules from nanomaterials and/or nanocomposite scaffolds. 59 Figure 14. Vascular Implants Since Dr. Jacques Puel first introduced the technique 1986 [306], coronary stent implantation has become routine worldwide as a standard approach to treating coronary artery disease. Two different types of vascular stents, bare-metal stents (BMSs) and drug-eluting stents (DESs), are widely used for treating the blocked coronary arteries. In-stent restenosis (ISR) caused by immune response or intimal hyperplasia frequently occurs in BMSs, whereas late stent thrombosis (ST) originating from drug-polymer matrix hypersensitivity and reduced re- endothelialization is quite common in DESs [307, 308]. To avoid these problems, novel methods involving the development of nanocomposite biomaterials are being intensely investigated [308]. Nanocomposite biomaterials, which have great potential to improve stent hemocompatibility, are candidates for the development of cardiovascular stents. Carbon dot-silver nanohybrid (CD-Ag) incorporating starch-modified hyperbranched polyurethane (HPU) nanocomposite (HPU/CD-Ag) exhibits self-expandability, and improved thermal, mechanical, and biological properties, as well as cytocompatibility, hemocompatibility, and infection resistance. These features support the use of HPU/CD-Ag as a material for self-expandable stents (Fig. 15a) [255]. In addition to hemocompatibility, vascular implants should also be able to prevent inflammation and ISR. The recent clinical failures of coronary artery dilation studies using everolimus-releasing poly(lactide) (PLA)-based absorbable vascular scaffolds may have been due to inflammatory reactions induced by acidic degradation products of PLA [207, 309]. Cobalt–chromium (Co-Cr) stents coated with surface-modified Mg(OH)2 nanoparticles (RA- Mg-OLA) and sirolimus-loaded PLGA showed significantly suppressed inflammatory 61 reactions induced by ISR and acidic degradation byproducts (Fig. 15b) [207]. Endothelialization plays an important role in the long-term success of cardiovascular implants [257]. Late Angiographic Stent Thrombosis (LAST) is a major limitation of DES, which often fails stent implantation in a clinical trial. LAST occurs as a result of delayed endothelialization of stent struts. From this standpoint, improving re-endothelialization or relining exposed regions represents the most efficient way to improve the clinical translation rate in the field of vascular stent implantation. Various techniques for achieving rapid re- endothelialization have been developed over the past few years, including active endothelial cell coating and the use of nanocomposites that promote endothelialization [308, 310]. For instance, a polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS)–poly(carbonate-urea) urethane (PCU) nanocomposite polymer was successfully coated onto a BMS surface, followed by covalent binding with anti-CD34, and the resultant nanocomposite polymer coating facilitated re- endothelialization by capturing endothelial progenitor cells via the antibody (Fig. 15c) [256]. A nanocomposite biomaterial patch of gold nanoparticles conjugated decellularized arterial tissue matrices implanted in a longitudinal arteriotomy of the porcine thoracic aorta exhibited good integration with host tissue, improved re-endothelialization, and did not fail over the 6- month implantation period [258]. Collagen/Au nanocomposite containing 43.5 ppm Au exhibits better biomechanical properties and thermal stability than pure collagen. Moreover, when Wharton’s jelly-derived MSC seeded collagen/Au nanocomposite coated catheters were implanted in the femoral artery of Sprague–Dawley rats, the material exhibited compliance, antithrombogenicity, biostability, endothelialization, and hemocompatibility [257]. Because the experiments on each nanocomposite were performed under different environments, future studies should seek to compare various nanocomposites under the same conditions to facilitate selection of the best nanocomposites for the vascular stent. 62 5.2.3. Dental implants Many types of dental materials have been developed to date, including temporary dressings, dental restorations (fillings, cement, resins, crowns, and bridges), dental impressions (negative imprints of teeth), prosthetic materials (dentures), and dental implants. For repair of dental caries and other defects, conventional mercury-containing amalgam alloys were replaced by composite resins in the 1960s due to their biocompatibility and aesthetic qualities, as well as the latter’s advantages in terms of operation technique [311, 312]. To further improve the mechanical, chemical, and biological properties of dental restorative resin composites, researchers have explored incorporation of inorganic nanomaterials (fillers) into resin matrix containing photocrosslinkable polymers (e.g., bisphenol A glycerolate dimethacrylate, triethylene glycol dimethacrylate, urethane dimethacrylate, etc.) [313]. The first inorganic nanomaterial used for dental resin-based composites was silica. Subsequently, many inorganic nanomaterials have been developed to improve the mechanical properties, fracture toughness, surface wetting properties, adhesion properties, and anti-caries function of dentin and enamel, as well as decrease tendency to stain and shrink. Resin-based composites incorporating methacrylated POSS exhibit reduced shrinkage [143], improved mechanical properties, and scratch resistance [259]. Dental resin based on bromide/cationic polymer (AgBr/NPVP) nanocomposite-modified poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) is cytocompatible, and just 0.1 wt.% of AgBr/NPVP is sufficient to suppress fungal growth [260]. Recently, Weir et al. reported effective dentin lesion remineralization using a nanocomposite consisting of resin [ethoxylated bisphenol A dimethacrylate (EBPADMA) and acidic pyromellitic glycerol dimethacrylate (PMGDM)] and CaP nanoparticles, indicating that resin/CaP nanocomposites are promising restorative materials that can both remineralize tooth lesions to protect tooth structures and inhibit secondary caries (Fig. 15d) [261]. 63 Nanocomposite biomaterials have also been developed for periodontal tissue engineering (Fig. 15e and f) [314]. The ultimate goal of periodontal therapy is to create an environment that helps patients maintain their dental health, comfort, and function. Various nanocomposite scaffolds studied in the context of bone regeneration, discussed in Section 5.2.1, represent promising candidate materials for periodontal tissue engineering. A major limitation of current synthetic dental implants is their failure to adapt to the local tissue environment. Although implant materials such as titanium and its ternary alloys have been successfully used for dental implants and prostheses for about 30 years, they are limited by the fact that cells do not adhere directly (or adequately) to most metallic surfaces. Accordingly, the goal of utilizing nanocoatings and nanocomposites is to modify the surface properties of dental implants to accelerate the healing process. For instance, hydroxyapatite-coated implants have been shown to interface strongly with bone at the implanted site in animal models [315]. Another major requirement of dental implants is wear resistance. Carbon-based nanomaterials have been used to increase the wear resistance of dental implants [316]; among them, diamond-like carbon coatings have received a deal of attention in recent years due to their inherent mechanical, chemical, and thermal properties [317]. Despite their advantages, they have several drawbacks such as high internal stress, poor adhesive properties, and high sensitivity to ambient conditions. To overcome these limitations, carbon nanocomposite coating (CNC) was performed on Co- Cr alloy plates using a C60 ion beam [317]. The CNC deposition significantly improved the biocompatibility and durability of the implant and improved new tissue formation without necrosis, indicating that this approach is promising for orthopedic and dental applications. For the complete and concurrent regeneration of the three types of periodontal tissues, the tissue- specific tri-layered nanocomposite hydrogel scaffold has been used (Fig. 15f) [20]. The porous tri-layered nanocomposite hydrogel scaffold is composed of chitin‐PLGA, nanobioactive glass 64 ceramic (nBGC), and/or growth factors. In vivo study showed that the cell-free construct completely regenerated the cementum, periodontal ligament, and alveolar bone in the periodontal defect. Recent developments in nanocomposites have improved dentistry and oral health care, and will further advance these fields in the near future. However, many obstacles continue to prevent the wider application of nanocomposite biomaterials for clinical use. Future studies should seek to develop nanocomposites capable of efficient cell–matrix interaction, growth factor delivery, and tissue regeneration at sites of dental tissue damage. Figure 15. Conclusion and perspective As the demand for highly functional materials in biomedical applications increases, use of organic/inorganic hybrid materials has become unavoidable. Hybrid biopolymers and 65 inorganic nanoparticles are attractive because they not only integrate the advantages of each component but also provide synergistic properties. Notably, the incorporation of inorganic nanoparticles can impart the extraordinary physical and chemical properties of the inorganic nanomaterial to the polymer matrix and thus compensate for low mechanical strength, a common and significant disadvantage of organic material. Representative organic/inorganic hybrids can be classified into nanoparticles and nanocomposites. Although such hybrid materials have been produced through a range of chemical synthesis methods, the current complex synthetic procedures are difficult to reproduce outside the laboratory at an industrial scale. Therefore, we require organic/inorganic hybrid materials that can be synthesized reproducibly and simply. Additionally, continuing efforts are needed to develop new types of organic/inorganic hybrid materials that overcome the limitations of existing hybrids. Because these organic/inorganic hybrids must be safe enough for clinical translation, they should be synthesized using biocompatible materials. Given the complexity of the physiological environment, more detailed studies of the in vivo behavior of organic/inorganic hybrid materials should be performed, along with well-designed pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic analyses. In particular, basic biological studies should be conducted to elucidate the interactions between organic/inorganic hybrid materials and biological components (i.e., proteins, cells, and tissues). The combination of inorganic nanoparticles with imaging modalities and organic polymers capable of drug delivery could be applied to theranostic approaches for various diseases. Exploitation of organic/inorganic hybrid materials in cancer immunotherapy, in conjunction with image guidance, represents a new strategy for improving their therapeutic efficacy. Advances in artificial intelligence (AI)/big data technology can accelerate the development of personalized materials by optimizing combinations of organic and inorganic materials, in line with the emerging idea of precision 66 medicine concept. Furthermore, organic/inorganic hybrid materials are advantageous for use in wearable electronic medical devices, which are attracting increasing attention. Specifically, the electrical, mechanical, physical, and chemical properties of a wearable device could be modulated by manipulating the type and composition of organic and inorganic constituents of its hybrid material components [318, 319]. Finally, multidisciplinary collaboration among experts in materials science and engineering, biotechnology, and medicine is necessary for the clinical application of organic and inorganic hybrid materials. Improvement of organic and inorganic hybrids through multidisciplinary feedback could facilitate the treatment of intractable diseases, thereby contributing significantly to the extension of human lifespan.
